questions.text: The doctor prescribes PHMB (polyhexamethylene biguanide) and propamidine to a patient with a corneal ulcer. Which of the following may be the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acanthamoeba The treatment for Acanthamoeba keratitis is as follows: Propamidine and PHMB (drug of choice). Chlorhexidine + Neomycin. Paromomycin + clotrimazole (hourly for a week, then taper over 3-4 months for epithelial lesions and 6-12 months for stromal lesions). Other treatment: Oral ketoconazole. Penetrating keratoplasty.

Highyeild:

Acanthamoeba keratitis Aetiology: Acanthamoeba castellanii, the causative organism, is a free-living genus of amoeba found in soil, fresh water, well water, sea water, sewage, and air. In humans, acanthamoeba causes: • Keratitis; Granulomatous encephalitis ; • fulminant meningoencephalitis. Mode of Infection Corneal infection with Acanthamoeba results from direct corneal contact with any material or water contaminated with the organism . Risk factors of contamination : Contact lens wearers using home-made saline (from contaminated tap water and saline tablets) is the commonest situation recognised for acanthamoeba infection in western countries. Trauma associated with contaminated matter such as vegetable matter, sail water diving, windblown contaminants. and hot tub use forms the non-contact lens-related situations. Trauma with organic matter and exposure to muddy water are the major (90% of cases) predisposing factors in developing countries. Opportunistic infection . Acanthamoeba keratitis can also occur as an opportunistic infection in patients with herpetic keratitis, bacterial keratitis, bullous keratopathy, and neuroparalytic keratitis. Clinical features: Symptoms: These vary from asymptomatic to foreign body sensation , mild pain to severe pain (out of proportion to the degree of inflammation due to perineural invasion ) , watering, photophobia , blepharospasm, and blurred vision . Signs: Gradual worsening keratitis Epithelial lesions: epithelial roughening and irregularities , Epithelial ridges , Radial keratoneuritis, reported in 50% of cases, seems to be a pathognomonic early sign; pseudodendrites formation occurs, and at this stage, it is commonly mistaken for herpes simplex keratitis. Limbal lesions: limbitis Stromal lesions: patchy and satellite stromal infiltrates • Ring infiltrates, central or paracentral, with overlying epithelial defects and underlying keratic precipitates Ring abscess Scleritis , usually anterior diffuse or nodular, can be contiguous with keratitis. Laboratory diagnosis : Corneal scrapings may be helpful in some cases, as under: Potassium hydroxide (KOH) is reliable in experienced hands for the recognition of Acanthamoeba cysts. Calcofluor white stain is a fluorescent brightener that stains the cysts of Acanthamoeba bright apple green under a fluorescence microscope. Lactophenol- stained cotton film is also useful for demonstrating of acanthamoeba cysts in the corneal scrapings. Culture on non-nutrient agar (E. coli-enriched ) may show trophozoites within 48 hours, which gradually turn into cysts. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for amoebic DNA is reported to be useful. Corneal biopsy, which may be required in non-conclusive cases, may be positive for amoebic cysts. Treatment: Specific treatment Topical antiamoebic agents include: Diamidines: Propamidine isethionate (0.1 %), and hexamidine (0. I%). Biguanides: Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) , 0.02% and chlorhexidine, 0.02%. Aminoglycosides: neomycin and Paromomycin Imidazoles:·clotrimazole and miconazole. Multiple drug therapy is needed for a long time (3-4 months) for early epithelial lesions and 6-12 months for stromal lesions. Any of the following combinations may be chosen: Propamidine or hexamidine + PHMB (drug of choice ) Chlorhexidine + Neomycin, Paromomycin + clotrimazole, miconazole or itraconazole . Frequency of instillation: hourly for a week, then taper slowly over 3-4 months for epithelial lesions and 6-12 months for stromal lesions. Oral ketoconazole 200 mg BID, or itraconazole 100 mg BD may be added in advanced cases. Long-term prophylactic therapy with PHMB , twice a day for a year, is recommended . Penetrating keratoplasty is frequently required in non-responsive cases.

Herpes Simplex : Definitive Treatment : Antiviral drugs are the first choice Acycloguanosine ( Aciclovir) (most commonly used antiviral drug). • Ganciclovir (0.15% gel) It is more toxic than aciclovir . • Trifluorothymidine 1 % drops • Adenine arabinoside (Vidarabine) 3% Option: B . Aspergillus: For filamentous fungi (Aspergillus and Fusarium) , natamycin (5%) eye drops (drug of choice) or amphotericin B (0.01 to 0.3%), or fluconazole (0.2%), miconazole (IO mg/ml), or voriconazole (10%) eye drops. Option: C . Cryptococcus: intrastromal injection of AB- amphotericin B +/- fluconazole .

Extraedge:

Early diagnosis and appropriate therapy are key to a good prognosis. A provisional diagnosis of AK can be made using clinical features and confocal microscopy, although a definitive diagnosis requires culture, histology, or identification of Acanthamoeba deoxyribonucleic acid by polymerase chain reaction . Routine use of tissue diagnosis is recommended, particularly for patients unresponsive to treatment for AK . Topical biguanides are the only effective therapy for the resistant encysted form of the organism in vitro, if not always in vivo.

questions.text: A patient using contact lenses develops a corneal infection, laboratory diagnosis of Acanthamoeba keratitis was established, and the following is the best drug for treatment:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polyhexamethylene (PHB) Acanthamoeba keratitis occurs in patients who sustain minor corneal trauma. This is usually associated with wearing contact lenses for a longer duration than prescribed . Amoebae can be introduced through environmental exposures such as swimming and showering while wearing contact lenses, contaminating lenses or cases with wet hands, "topping off" lens solution bottles , or using contaminated contact lens solutions, especially homemade solutions. Rare reports cite radial keratotomies preceding this infection. Medical treatment consists of topical antimicrobial agents, which can achieve high concentrations at the site of the infection. Because the cystic form may be highly resistant to therapy, a combination of agents is generally used. Many authorities recommend a combination of chlorhexidine (0.02%) and polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB, 0.02%) for treating both the trophozoites and cysts.

Microscopy showed macrophages like cells on culturing the corneal scraping over a non-nutrient agar enriched with E. coli, There were plaque formations. Which organism is most likely?

Acanthamoeba The given clinical scenario with red eye and features of keratitis and H/O trauma with vegetative matter and corneal examination showing a dendritic ulcer. Microscopy showed macrophage- like cells on culturing the corneal scraping over a non-nutrient agar enriched with E. coli. There were plaque formations . All these features are suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Herpes Simplex: Clinical features : Ocular lesion: Typically, these occurs as unilateral blepharoconjunctivitis characterised by acute follicular conjunctivitis with regional lymphadenitis, is the usual and sometimes only manifestation of the primary infection. • Keratitis. Cornea is involved in about 50% of the cases. The keratitis can occur as a coarse punctate or diffuse branching epithelial keratitis that does not usually involve the stroma. STROMAL NECROTIC KERATITIS, DISCIFORM KERATITIS Option C: Candida: Symptoms are less marked than in an equal-sized bacterial ulcer, and the overall course is slow and torpid. Signs are more prominent than symptoms . Corneal ulcers is greyish- white, dry-looking, and have elevated rolled out margins. Pigmented ulcer (brownish) may be caused by some species of fungi, e.g., dematiaceous fungi. Delicate, feathery finger-like extensions are present in the surrounding stroma under the intact epithelium. Sterile immune rings (yellow line of demarcation) may be present where fungal antigen and hose antibodies meet. Multiple, small satellite lesions may be present around the ulcer. Option D: Adenovirus: Patients with the complex of “ epidemic keratoconjunctivitis ” complain about unilateral itching, tearing, burning, and foreign body sensations, as well as photophobia. In cases of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (AHC) , extensive epibulbar and tarsal hemorrhages and pre cervical lymph node enlargement may manifest as early as 48 hours after the first symptoms in >90% of patients. questions.text: A 50-year-old man develops a mass on the back of his hand. The lesion somewhat resembles a "volcano" and consists of a round, firm, flesh colored, 1-cm nodule with sharply rising edges and a central crater. Keratotic debris can be expressed from the central crater. The lesion has developed very rapidly over about a three-month period. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratoacanthoma This is a keratoacanthoma. These lesions have the distinctive appearance described in the question stem, and tend to occur on sun-exposed areas, including the face, the forearm, and the dorsum of the hand. These lesions microscopically closely resemble squamous cell carcinoma but are now considered benign . They may resolve spontaneously, and some authors suggest that they may not need resection. However, they are usually respected since both patient and physician often feel uncomfortable with neglecting them without having a definitive diagnosis and being absolutely certain they will spontaneously regress.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Lipoma : Lipoma causes a soft subcutaneous mass. Option: C . Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma usually causes a pigmented lesion, often with feathery edges suggesting invasion. Option: D . Pyogenic granuloma: Pyogenic granuloma causes a red mass, often at a site of previous injury.
